instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message: 820 3209, no image/no chime fan spins. PPBUS 8.39v, VCORE is present, missing <SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message: No, no sound at all, dont even get a chime

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message:
Do you get USB activity?
Disconnect LIO flex and try USB connector from MLB.

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message: JohnB I inspected <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3 area like you mentioned, and while I did not see any corrosion, it does look like someone has reworked this area in the past, most likey <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> has been replaced.

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message: Inspect <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3 for being blown and inspect traces to and from them to <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> has proper resistance, and has .337v on <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TON</SIGNAL>

<RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> has proper resistance, and has 1.796v on <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_UGATE1_R</SIGNAL>

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message:
You have VCORE, so most likely no problem at all on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> area.
Will still be good to post L7550 voltage.

"Do you get USB activity?
Disconnect LIO flex and try USB connector from MLB."
???

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message: 2inform, I sm not getting USB activity, also, something I over looked <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is present, <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> is missing.

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message:
If no USB activity, board is stuck; no reason to look for video...

Check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL>.
If any missing, post <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>.

Check for 25MHz at <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK25M_SB</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> being low could be your problem it's supposed to be 3.3

threads.title: 820 3209 no image
threads.message:
I think <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> has a weak pull-up inside PCH.
Maybe some chip connected there is throwing signal down, or crap under PCH.
Maybe you can force it with external 33-47K to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, worth to tray.
First see if reflow PCH to 180 degrees help; use quality flux, not "chinese honey".
